subject: Re: test last
msgSnippet: ... Even this is IMO not at all unfortunate. Why should it be? Test-first is good - but I doubt that this means that you *never* write tests later to cover
messageBody:
> From: "Coolspot714" <Coolspot714@...>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Harald Mueller" <harald.m.mueller@b...>
> wrote:
> > > my question concerns a different approach of writing tests. I'm
> in the
> > > unfortunate situation of having to write tests for an existing
> > > application(I haven't been involved in the development). ´
> >
> > Unfortunate? This is the standard situation in most processes: Test
> are
> > written after development or in parallel to it. What's so
> unfortunate about
> > writing tests?
>
> As Chris Dollin stated, "unfortunate" refers to writing the test
> post-hoc.

Even this is IMO not at all unfortunate. Why should it be? Test-first is
good - but I doubt that this means that you *never* write tests later to
cover additional cases. Of course, with test-first you usually have a
set of test to start from, which you can copy-paste (or even put into a
fine test-case architecture) to extend. But writing from scratch
afterwards should be as much fun as test-first - IF (big if) the
software is designed for testability.
Still, if there are enough public methods around, it should be possible
to test "just these" - and either this finds enough bugs for keeping
development busy for some time; or if not, you can talk to the guys
there (who will sit around and fiddle with their thumbs) to refactor to
more testability ...

> > Technically, I do not see why you shouldn't be able to write unit
> tests for
> > selected classes with JUnit - if the design is suitable.
>
> Is there infomation somewhere in the net about whether or not a design
> is suitable for being tested with JUnit?

I write testcases routinely (well, a few per week :-) ) for a project
which does only in-system testing. They have so many public methods that
JUnit is easy to apply to it (of course, this is NOT AT ALL object
testing ... but I really dont care as long as enough of the system gets
tested; and enough bugs are found: A successful test is a test which
finds bugs).
Slowly, I also try to write object tests - but this is really low-prio
right now (I might show you all a piece of the software and its unit
tests in a few weeks and ask for your comments on my way of making it
object-testable - using "Junit Recipes" advice).


> It is about functional correctness. I did load tests using "The
> Grinder 3" (can be found at sourceforge), which is free. There are a
> lot of open source load testing tools, so they are not necessarily
> expensive.

Good to know - I'll tell that the people in our company who told me that
they couldn't afford load test tools ....

>
>
> > * to which level of granularity, e.g.
> > - methods of single classes; or of facade classes hiding a
> complete
> > "system";
> > - single web page clicks, or whole work-flows;
>
> That is to be determined and I know only we can do that.
>
>
> > * to which level of quality, e.g.
> > - only critical functions (e.g. defined by "draw most bug reports
> in the
> > last 3 monts");
> > - everything to some coverage level; then you need to decide on
> > -- the coverage level ("80%" is in "industry standard"; "100%
> feasible
> > coverage" is the only sensible standard)
>
> I assume the level of quality depends on the level of granularity.

I'm not sure - for me, the two are orthogonal. The latter is more driven
by the resources (people and time) you have - you have to stop when
money's out ...

>
> > -- the type of coverage (code coverage; or some "feature coverage"
> - all
> > the features down written in some specification or documentation)
>
> Code coverage is not an issue here but "feature coverage" is. Is
> "feature coverage" a common term?

I fear not, after looking on the internet. I'll check in my few testing
books what they call it.

Regards
Harald M. Mueller
